Archaeologists are scientists who are interested in history and human history. They can tell from remains of a body if they were male or female, age when they died, what they died off and how long they were drinking mothers milk.

Archaeologists use remarkable techniques to uncover details about ancient lives. From bones, they can determine sex, age, diseases, and even the age at which individuals stopped breastfeeding by analyzing teeth. They also explore language development, finding that Neanderthals likely had speech capabilities based on anatomical features like larger breathing-control nerves. Tool analysis reveals that most Neanderthals were right-handed, a trait linked to brain lateralization and language. These findings highlight the depth of information archaeologists can extract, offering insights into the health, behavior, and communication of our ancestors.

Archaeologists, who study human and prehuman history, can tell from a skeleton whether the deceased was male or female. They can determine at what age they died and if they suffered any conditions. This applies to skeletons which can be tens of thousands of years old. They can even determine at what age a human stopped drinking their mother's milk, based on the formation of their teeth. There is an airpipe present in both human and ape fossils, but the pipe is larger in humans, most likely due to our need to control our breathing more closely in order to speak. The pipe is also larger in neanderthals. The majority of neanderthals were right handed. Handedness is considered to be connected to language, which indicates that neanderthals did have some form of language system.

Archaeologists can discern a great deal of information from studying bones. They can determine things like sex, age and even when the individual stopped drinking their mother's milk just by the composition of their teeth.   It is also possible to learn things about the history of the development of human language. For example, the air canal with the human body is larger than in other animals, perhaps because this is required for the production of speech. This canal is also larger in Neanderthals.   Lastly, archaeologists can also determine the handedness of individuals based on the tools they created, and believe that handedness is also linked to language.

The study of archaeology and the associated fields of anthropology and paleontology provide valuable insights into the lives of our ancient ancestors, including the Neanderthals. Through the analysis of physical remains, including bones and teeth, scientists can glean information about an individual's sex, age at death, and even details about their health. For example, the dental structure can indicate when a child transitioned from nursing to consuming solid foods, which is critical for understanding childhood development in prehistoric populations.  Furthermore, the examination of anatomical features, such as the size of the nerve controlling respiration, suggests that the capacity for speech and complex communication may not be exclusive to modern humans. The fact that Neanderthals had a similar enlargement in this nerve canal points toward the possibility that they had a level of vocal control and, consequently, some form of language.  Tool analysis further supports this view, indicating that Neanderthals exhibited a preference for right-handedness when crafting their tools. This behavioral trait is often linked to lateralization in the brain, which is associated with language and cognitive processes. The correlation between handedness, tool use, and the potential for language implies that the cognitive capabilities of Neanderthals might have been more advanced than previously thought.  Overall, these findings collectively enhance our understanding of the cognitive and communicative abilities of Neanderthals and suggest a richer and more complex social structure than earlier models proposed. These insights not only inform us about Neanderthals but also about the evolutionary pathways that led to the development of modern human language and societal structures.

Using modern techniques, archaeologists can tell a lot about human development. For example, they can tell when someone from the distant past stopped drinking their mother’s milk by analysing the development of their teeth. It is also possible to deduce how sapiens learnt to speak, by comparison with Neanderthals, because they have a wider breathing passage. Which hand early man favoured also provides information that suggests Neanderthals had a basic speech ability.

Archaeologists, who study human history and prehistory, can determine various details about ancient individuals from their skeletal remains, such as their sex, age, and the diseases they may have experienced. By analyzing the composition of teeth, they can even identify the age at which someone, who lived tens of thousands of years ago, stopped breastfeeding.  They also investigate the potential language abilities of our ancestors and relatives. For example, humans have a larger nerve controlling breathing compared to apes, likely to enable the precise control needed for speech. This feature is reflected in the larger nerve canal found in both humans and Neanderthals.  Additionally, by examining tools made by Neanderthals, archaeologists have determined that most were right-handed. Since handedness is thought to be connected to the development of language, this serves as further evidence that Neanderthals likely had a form of language.

Archaeologists can determine many factors about our long-dead human ancestors through studying their remains. For example, archaeologists can analyse bones to determine the age, sex, and general health of their owners. They can even determine at what age these ancestors stopped drinking milk from their mothers based on their teeth.  Archaeologists have studied Neanderthal remains to try to understand how capable they were of speech and language.   It is thought, based on the tools discovered and studied by archaeologists, that Neanderthals were right-handed.

Archaeologists are able to tell from bones of humans thousand years old whether the person was male or female, their age and - from their teeth - at what age the infant stopped drinking their mother's milk.  It was also possible to tell from tools which hand was dominant in Neanderthals (most were right handed) and that enlarged areas of their nasal canal indicated greater breathing capacity which in turn indicates they probably had some capacity for speech - which great apes do not.

Archaeologists, scientists who study the historical remains of humans, are able to tell, by studying their bones, whether someone was male or female, how old they were when they died and, by examining their teeth, what age they stopped drinking their mother's milk.  Archaeologists are also able to infer things about how humans and our cousins lived. For example, the nerve controlling breathing in humans is more sensitive compared to that of apes, likely due to the increased sensitivity of breathe require for talking. The canal surrounding the nerve is enlarged in humans as a result. This nerve is also larger in Neanderthals, suggesting that they may have been able to communicate via talking.   Archaeologists have also been able to determine that the majority of Neanderthals were right handed, which is a trait that is thought to be influenced by linguistics - providing further evidence that Neanderthals had language and could communicate through talking.

Entomologists are the scientists who study insects. Entomologist have worked hard to understand how insects work and how they understand and see the world.Entomologists have used special displays to show images for less than the blink of an eye and electrodes to record how  cells in the flies brain react. Because of these these techniques, they have shown that some flies can perceive images that are displayed for just three milliseconds which is about ten times shorter than a single movie frame and of which there are 24 per second.also entomologists who study the hair of crickets have shown that these microscopic hairs that can be found on antenna organs attached to the crickets rear, are perhaps the most sensitive organs in the animal kingdom. Researchers measured how the hair reacts to stimuli, such as laser Doppler velocimtry which is technique capable of finding the most smallest of movements. They showed that the hair could react to changes in the motion of the air that had less energy than a single photon.

Experts in the study of insects, entomologists have discovered incredible abilities in these little creatures by employing state-of-the-art research methods. According to studies, flies, for instance, can process visuals in as little as three milliseconds, which is around ten times faster than the flicker of a single movie frame. Researchers found this incredible achievement using sophisticated brain activity sensors and high-speed displays. Another remarkable discovery by scientists is that the tiny hairs on a cricket's rear antennae are so sensitive that they can detect air movements with an energy level equivalent to one photon. These findings demonstrate not just the extraordinary senses of insects but also the meticulous techniques and inventiveness that underpin current entomological research.

The techniques they employed involve mapping the brain cell response using electrodes, scanning of the brain sections, for example. The entomologists have also discovered that the hair on the antenna like structure attached to the back of a cricket could sense the air movement involving the energy as tiny as a light particle (photon ), by using Laser-Doppler Velocimetry.

Entomologists study insects, some have specialised in how insects perceive and interact with the world around them. Some have created special displays to measure how flies see things and have established that some flies can see images that are displayed for 10 times shorter than movie images (24 frames per second). Other entomologists have studied the hairs that are on the back of crickets and established that they may be the most sensitive organs in the animal kingdom. The hairs are capable of detecting movement that is less than the equivalent of a light photon's energy.

Entomologists study insects in their area of science. There are specialized entomologists that have uncovered further understanding regarding insects perception of the world around them, and have been able to reveal remarkable abilities. Entomologists have been studying how flies visual perception works, and have used specialized displays to show images for less than the blink of a human eye, utilizing electrodes to record how individual cells in the field's brains might react; as well as ultra precise electron microscopy to inspect their eyes.  Thanks to this research, scientists have shown some flies and insects can perceive images that have been displayed for only three milliseconds - which is a mere thousandth of a second, which can easily be understood as ten times shorter than a typical movie frame, coming in at 24 frames a second.   Entomologists studying specifically the hairs on crickets have shown microscopic hairs, which are found on antenna like organs on the crickets backside are the most sensitive organ in the insect kingdom. The scientists used precision techniques to measure how these hairs reacted to stimuli too, using stimuli like the laser-doppler velocimetry, which is a technique that is capable of detecting the smallest of movements/twitches. Using this showed the researchers that the cricket's hairs reacted to changes in the motion of the air that used less physically charged energy than one particle of light, so less than even a single photon.
